bibl.title: Letter from Carlos Coello to [Hugh S. Cumming], January 18, 1923

div1.p: Coello reports on cases of hemorrhagic jaundice in Guayaquil, Ecuador.

div1.head: Letter from Carlos Coello to [Hugh S. Cumming], January 18, 1923
div1.opener:
Sent to I. H. B
Feb 10/23 with
Comment as en-
dorsement,
C
Copy.
Treasury Department,
United States
Public Health Service,
Guayaquil, Ecuador January 18, 1923.
The Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
Answering your letter of November 25, 1922 in reference to the in-
formation contained in “The Journal of the American Medical Association,”
about the cases of hemorrhagic jaundice that have occurred in Guayaquil,
I have the honor to inform as follows:

During 1921 two cases of Icterohemorragic Leptospirosis were re-
ported in Guayaquil. They recovered. The diagnosis was made clinically,
and a microorganism morphologically equal to the spiroqueta of Ido was
found in the bladder of these patients.

During 1922 seven cases occurred, according to official statistics,
as follows:

June 15, Septtember 6: 15: 16: 18; October 17 and December 28.
Four of them died; all of them before the sixth day.
No post-mortem was performed.

Except the case of Sept. 6th. all the diagnosis were made clinical-
ly only, the signs and symptoms being more or less typical of Weil's
disease.

The case of which a complete laboratory investigation took place
was the one reported second in the year (Sept. 6) by Profesor Carbo Noboa,
a member of the “Sociedad Medico-Quirurgica.”

The laboratory findings confirmed the diagnosis: typical symptoms
and anatomical changes were observed in guinea-pigs injected with blood
from the patient, treated after the Noguchi's technic, and a germ with
all the characteristics of the Ido's microorganism was isolated from the
blood of the heart and from sections of the kidneys of one of the guinea-
pigs.

Further investigations are carried on at present, and I will be
very pleased to inform the Bureau of any new findings as soon as they may
be announced.
I am enclosing a reprint of the paper on the case of Sept. 6, 1922.

No new case of this condition either in the hospitals or in the
private practice has been reported since December 28, 1922.

Any other information in this connection which might be of inter-
est, I will have the honor to report, according to the instructions of
the Bureau.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, (Signed) Carlos Coello,
Acting Assistant Surgeon.
